content.description: Stay to the right of the notch as you ascend, guidebook describes a ramp - I found it easier to just take the path of least resistance up to the notch. The climbing down low is very easy and doesn't warrant pro. When you get to the notch sling a knob and enjoy the views as you scamper to the top.
content.protection: I used a purple Camalot and I believe a yellow alien, ran it out pretty much to the notch. Two solid anchors at the top.
content.location: There is a nice flat spot in a corner for the belayer, protected from the wind and afternoon sun. Good, easy fun route to do in the afternoon if things are getting a bit warm.

content.description: The left (north) most route on the west face of Poultry Pillar. With overhanging jug pulls onto the summit, the last 20 feet are what really make this route worth doing.
content.protection: Really good pro options pretty much everywhere. A few offset cams could be the bees knees at the start, as the bottom cracks are flared, but I found ample opportunities for hexes, nuts, and DMM offsets.  There is a set of cold shuts with a rappel ring on the south end of the summit. There is also a bolt for clipping into while setting up the rappel, although it's not needed.
content.location: This route is on Poultry Pillar, a spur pillar of Castle Rock. Start at the same point for Drumstick Direct (the bottom of the face), but traverse left about 15 feet, either right away or gradually. Rappel from cold shuts on the summit.

content.description: Great trad lead for the entry-level trad climber.  Lot's of good protection, a bit slabby and exposed.  Really enjoyed this route as an experienced sport climber new to trad.
content.location: Starts at the base of the two big parallel cracks at the bottom of Poultry Pillar's west face (see attached.)
